thread.title: Joe Hockey, in political limbo, has got his groove back
thread.title_full: Joe Hockey, in political limbo, has got his groove back | afr.com

author: Fleur Anderson
title: Joe Hockey, in political limbo, has got his groove back
text:
Australia's treasurer of two years is not slinking away quietly before Turnbull's reshuffle next Monday. Alex Ellinghausen Share on twitter by Fleur Anderson The unkind might suggest Joe Hockey with his days numbered as Treasurer is a dead man walking, a political wraith practising zombie economics until the final death blow.
The reality, on Day Two of the Age of Malcolm, is somehow the very opposite.
With a kind of gallows humour, Australia's treasurer of two years is not slinking away quietly before Turnbull's reshuffle next Monday.
Sure, Hockey'd had to postpone the government's long-awaited response to the Murray review into the financial system on Tuesday, given the chaos of the previous night's leadership change.
But by Wednesday he was back on track, fronting the cameras in Parliament's blue room to present with Tax Commission Chris Jordan the government's legislation on multinational profit shifting.
There were rumours Hockey was to be offered the Cabinet portfolio of communications, which include regulation of the media industry. Given there was that defamation action against Fairfax Media oh so recently, could this be the reason behind Hockey's return of bon homie?
A psychologist might instead point to that lightness of being, that odd euphoria, that happens when the worst has happened (e.g. you are about to lose your job) and yet, here you are – still alive and breathing.
There were tough and even disrespectful questions thrown at him, yet Hockey did not lose his cool.
 "Are you gutless for not resigning as Treasurer?" one person asked.
Hockey would have been forgiven throwing a shoe at the ill-mannered question but instead turned his head and ignored it.
What did he say to Turnbull, what did Turnbull say to him? Who's been leaking from Cabinet? The questions came thick and fast.
"No," he said, keeping schtum​.
There would be no truth bombs or bitter recriminations. Not now at least.
"I am an instinctively loyal person," Hockey said.
Does he still want the job, and finish what he started two years ago?
"What I laid down 20 years ago in my maiden speech, it hasn't changed. I want to do my very best for my country. Simple as that."
By question time, Hockey threw himself into the fray with joie de vivre. And he answered with barely concealed hilarity, an attempted attack by shadow assistant treasurer Andrew Leigh whether Hockey asked rich man Turnbull for permission before launching a crackdown on some of the world's favourite tax havens, Bermuda, the Isle of Man and the Cayman Island.
"I love this guy," Hockey guffawed. Did he consult Turnbull? He consulted his whole party room that very Tuesday!
"Put up your hand if you support what we're doing on multinational tax," Hockey said to his colleagues.
Even man and women from the government side, from frontbenchers to backbenchers raised their hands and cheered.
Disunity? What disunity. JoHo's got his groove back.
